PROJECT PREPARATORY TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
Justification 
 
1.  The project preparatory technical assistance (PPTA) is necessary to define the scope of 
the project to optimize the development potential of Fukang City, and Hutubi and Qitai counties in 
Changji Hui Autonomous Prefecture (Changji), Xinjiang Uygur Autonomous Region (Xinjiang). 
The objectives of the PPTA are to (i) ensure the project design is suitable for Asian Development 
Bank (ADB) financing by identifying the most appropriate project components and providing 
innovative  ideas,  concepts,  management  approaches,  and  technology  to  enhance  project 
impacts; (ii) review proposed project components based on detailed due diligence assessment of 
technical, economic and financial, governance, safeguards and poverty and social, and project 
risk and mitigation measures; (iii) provide trainings to increase institutional capacity on effective 
project development and implementation procedures; and (iv) formulate measures to ensure the 
long-term sustainability of the project facilities, by improving the management and governance 
capacity of the executing agency, implementing agencies, project management offices (PMOs), 
and project implementing units (PIUs).

Cost Estimate and Proposed Financing Arrangement  
 
3.  The PPTA is estimated to cost $780,000 equivalent, of which $650,000 will be financed 
on  a  grant  basis  by  ADB’s  Technical  Assistance  Special  Fund  (TASF-other  sources)  and 
$130,000 from the Multidonor Trust Fund under the Water Financing Partnership Facility1 and 
administered by ADB. The government will provide counterpart support in the form of counterpart 
accommodation and transport, remuneration and per diem of counterpart staff, surveys and 
investigations, and other in-kind miscellaneous administration and support contributions, such as 
data and information relevant to the project. The detailed cost estimate is presented in Table A3.2.

Consulting Services 
 
4.  In accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2013, as amended from 
time to time), a consulting firm will be engaged using the quality- and cost-based selection method 
with full technical proposal and a quality-cost ratio of 90:10. Individual consultants will also be 
engaged using ADB guidelines. The outline terms of reference for the PPTA consultants are 
described in paragraphs 5–8.

5.  Technical.  Seven  experts  (total  of  23.5  person-months)  will  (i)  review  the  regional 
master plans for Urumqi-Changji region, transport plans in North Tianshan Mountain region, and 
urban master plans and sector plans for Fukang, Hutubi, and Qitai; (ii) review existing and 
projected population of the project city and counties in relation with wider regional trends and 
growth; (iii) review the existing situation, problems and constraints, demands, and forecasts of 
urban  roads,  water  supply,  wastewater  management,  solid  waste  management,  and  other 
services  in  project  city  and  counties;  (iv)  undertake  a  technical  review  of  the  design  and 
feasibility analyses and ensure that technical alternatives are carefully assessed and prepare a 
technical analysis for all subcomponents in project city and counties; (v) review and take into 
account national and international good practices, applicable standards, codes, design, and 
construction  guidelines;  (vi)  identify  ways  to  optimize  the  designs  and  propose  alternative 
designs or technologies and assess the final selection; (vii) update cost estimates; (viii) identify 
priority investments suitable for ADB project support; (ix) prepare baseline and performance 
indicators for project outputs; and (x) make recommendations and support the Changji PMO to 
establish  suitable  institutional  arrangements  for  project  implementation  and  operation  and 
maintenance  (O&M)  in  project  city  and  counties  (including  identifying  responsibilities  and 
funding sources). 
 
6.  Financial and economic. Four experts (total of 7.0 person-months) will (i) review the 
economic rationale and investment priorities taking into account not only the city and county level 
but  wider  regional  perspectives,  and  analyze  project  economic  impacts  based  on  improved 
accessibility  to  urban  services  and  economic  opportunities;  (ii)  analyze  financial  information 
relevant to the project and review policy and practice relating to financing and O&M of urban 
infrastructure services; (iii) analyze alternative options for each component and ensure that the 
least-cost option is identified; (iv) analyze water, wastewater, and solid waste management tariffs 
and their financial sustainability; (v) undertake financial and economic analyses according to ADB 
guidelines,  including  appropriate  internal  rates  of  return  of  project  components;  (vi)  analyze 
historical financial statements and financial performance of the implementing agencies and PIUs 
to  evaluate  their  financial  capacity  regarding  counterpart  funding  availability,  cost  recovery, 
borrowing capacity, and subsidies; (vii) review detailed cost tables, annual fund requirement, and 
review and identify the project financing plan; (viii) conduct financial management assessment on 
Fukang,  Hutubi,  and  Qitai;  (iv)  recommend  an  appropriate  funds  flow  mechanism  and 
disbursement procedures for project implementation; and (x) develop appropriate design and 
monitoring indicators of the project. 
 
7.  Safeguards and social development. Six experts (total of 15.0 person-months) will 
(i) orient on ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement (2009) and social analysis requirements, and

4 
provide analysis to bridge any gaps between ADB and policies of the People’s Republic of China; 
(ii)  recommend  measures  necessary  to  avoid  adverse  environment,  social  safeguards,  and 
cultural impacts or, if unavoidable, identify measures to minimize, mitigate, and compensate for 
such impacts; (iii) conduct socioeconomic survey of affected persons and project beneficiaries; 
(iv) based on meaningful consultation with the affected ethnic minority communities, assess 
potential adverse and positive effects of the project; (v) conduct a gender-sensitive assessment 
on the affected ethnic minorities’ project perception and its impact on their social, economic, and 
cultural status; (vi) conduct safeguard due diligence for project associated facilities; (vii) review 
and assist the executing and implementing agencies to (a) prepare the project ethnic minority 
development  plan,  environmental  management  plan,  gender  action  plan,  initial  environment 
examination, resettlement plans, and social development action plan in accordance with ADB’s 
Safeguard  Policy  Statement  (2009);  and  (b)  undertake  public  consultation  with  regard  to 
resettlement compensation, relocation choices and entitlements, initial environment examination, 
and  establish  a  project-level  grievance  redress  mechanism  for  safeguards;  (viii)  assess  the 
implementation and monitoring capacity of the executing and implementing agencies for all plans 
and recommend capacity building measures, and (ix) prepare a consultation and participation plan 
for project implementation. 
 
8.  Governance. Three experts (total of 5.5 person-months) will (i) conduct procurement 
capacity assessment and governance risk assessment; (ii) conduct enterprise surveys at local 
industrial zones and surveys among target groups; (iii) identify training equipment, books, and 
learning materials; and upgrade information management system to meet the skills needs of 
enterprises and target groups; (iv) assess institutional capacity of the implementing agencies and 
PIUs to supervise construction, O&M, and manage project facilities; (v) propose necessary O&M 
equipment needed under the project and prepare institutional capacity development programs for 
each PIU and facility operator to ensure sustainability of the project; (vi) closely collaborate with 
the other team members to analyze policy recommendation on water tariff reform; (vii) propose 
efficient and operationally sound organizational framework of the executing and implementing 
agencies, and PIUs for implementation  and operational  phases of the project; (viii) prepare 
project’s capacity building program and formulate appropriate indicators to monitor the outcomes; 
and (ix) design and conduct training workshops on ADB policies and requirements. 
 
Implementation Arrangements 
 
9.  The  Changji  Prefecture  Housing  and  Urban-Rural  Construction  Bureau  will  be  the 
executing agency. In-kind contributions from the government will include (i) office accommodation 
and transport; (ii) local support staff; and (iii) draft feasibility reports, domestic environmental 
reports, resettlement plans, and other data and information relevant to the project. PPTA funds 
will be disbursed in accordance with ADB’s Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, 
as amended from time to time). The proposed PPTA implementation schedule is in Table A3.4.
